questions.question: What is wort?
questions.correct: A sweet infusion of water made from malted cereal grains used in the brewing process.
incorrect: The result of soaking grain in cold water overnight.
A sweet infusion of water made from hops used in the brewing process.
The process of roasting cereal grains prior to mashing.
A raised skin blemish commonly blamed on toads and witches.
questions.explanation: Wort is the sugary liquid produced during mashing that yeast ferment into alcohol and CO₂.

questions.question: What is the purpose of malting cereal grains?
questions.correct: To activate enzymes that convert carbohydrates into simple sugars usable by yeast.
incorrect: To sterilize grain so it won’t contribute flavor.
To add bitterness to balance sweetness in the finished beer.
To remove the husk so mashing water can penetrate more easily.
To politely introduce the grain to hops so they become friends.
questions.explanation: Malting (moistening and germination, then halted) develops enzymes that later create fermentable sugars.

questions.question: What is mashing?
questions.correct: Mixing hot water with malted grain to dissolve and extract sugars into wort.
incorrect: Boiling hops to extract bitterness and aroma.
Grinding malted grain into flour for baking.
A cold-soak of grain used to clarify beer.
A traditional dance performed to appease the yeast.
questions.explanation: Mashing extracts sugars and other compounds from malt into the liquid called wort.

questions.question: Why are bittering/stabilizing agents like hops added before fermentation?
questions.correct: They make wort less hospitable to bacteria while allowing yeast to work.
incorrect: They feed yeast with extra oxygen.
They caramelize sugars to prevent fermentation.
They raise the pH so proteins precipitate instantly.
They scare away unruly microbes with their intimidating cones.
questions.explanation: Hops and similar agents inhibit many bacteria, improving microbial stability pre-fermentation.

questions.question: What is the most commonly used grain in beer?
incorrect: Wheat.
Rye.
Rice.
Quinoa grown by hipster gnomes.
questions.explanation: Although many grains are used, barley is the most common base for beer.

questions.question: Which list contains other grains commonly used in brewing?
incorrect: Oats, spelt, amaranth, chia only.
Barley, cocoa nibs, coffee beans.
Corn husks, bamboo, pine needles.
Only grains that come with free stickers.
questions.explanation: Besides barley, brewers may use grains like wheat, rye, rice, and maize.

questions.question: What is the most common bittering/stabilizing agent in modern beer?
incorrect: Heather tips.
Mugwort.
Gruit herb blends.
A handful of jalapeños for excitement.
questions.explanation: Hops are the standard, though historical and regional alternatives exist.

questions.question: Which are examples of non-hop bittering or stabilizing agents used historically?
questions.correct: Mugwort, heather tips, gruit herbs, fruit extracts.
incorrect: Sea salt, oyster shells, kelp strands.
Cinnamon sticks, vanilla pods, cacao nibs only.
Only lab-grade bitterness powder.
Leftover salad greens from lunch.
questions.explanation: Before hops dominated, various herbs and botanicals were used for bitterness and stability.

questions.question: Why is wort cooled before adding yeast?
questions.correct: Because boiling temperatures would kill the yeast.
incorrect: Because cold wort contains more sugar.
Because yeast only reproduce in ice crystals.
Because hops won’t dissolve unless it’s cold.
Because the wort needs a nap after a long boil.
questions.explanation: Yeast has a survivable temperature range; hot wort would kill or severely stress it.

questions.question: What happens during fermentation?
questions.correct: Yeast consume sugars and produce ethanol and carbon dioxide.
incorrect: Sugars are converted to protein and vitamins.
Water becomes alcohol via osmosis.
Hops transform into sugar.
Yeast whisper inspirational quotes to the bubbles.
questions.explanation: Alcoholic fermentation is the metabolic conversion of sugars to ethanol and CO₂ by yeast.

questions.question: What temperatures do ale yeasts generally prefer?
incorrect: Only room temperature if the room is complimenting them.
questions.explanation: Ales typically ferment warmer than lagers, producing more esters and phenols.

questions.question: What temperatures do lager yeasts generally prefer?
incorrect: Whatever temperature the nearest snowman recommends.
questions.explanation: Lager yeasts work best cooler than ale yeasts, producing cleaner profiles.

questions.question: Which statement best describes ale yeast behavior?
questions.correct: Top-fermenting; often rises and forms noticeable foam.
incorrect: Bottom-fermenting; settles quietly at the start.
Only ferments in complete darkness.
Needs to be shaken every hour to keep working.
Floats to the top to check its social media.
questions.explanation: Ale yeasts are commonly called top-fermenting and often produce a thick krausen.

questions.question: Which statement best describes lager yeast behavior?
questions.correct: Bottom-fermenting; tends to settle toward the bottom.
incorrect: Top-fermenting; forms heavy foam on the surface.
Requires daily sunlight to remain active.
Ferments while suspended by tiny parachutes.
Only works if you hum lullabies to it.
questions.explanation: Lager yeasts are described as bottom-fermenting and generally settle more than ale yeasts.

questions.question: What flavors and aromas are esters and phenols commonly associated with in ales?
incorrect: Esters: salty; Phenols: sour only.
Esters: bitter; Phenols: sweet only.
Esters: smoky; Phenols: chocolaty.
Esters: grape soda; Phenols: mystery jellybeans.
questions.explanation: Ale fermentations often exhibit ester-driven fruitiness and phenolic spice/complexity.

questions.question: What does the term 'lager' relate to in its German origin?
questions.correct: Storage at cool temperatures (from the verb 'lagern').
incorrect: Boiling at high temperatures to concentrate flavor.
Adding hops late for aroma.
Filtering through wood chips.
Keeping beer in a secret underground dragon cave.
questions.explanation: The term lager comes from 'lagern', to store—reflecting cool storage practiced historically.

questions.question: Why are some early beers grouped as 'Other' in yeast type?
questions.correct: They relied on wild yeast cultures rather than cultivated ale or lager strains.
incorrect: They used no yeast at all.
They were brewed exclusively with fruit juice.
They were fermented by hops instead of yeast.
They were just vibes in a barrel.
questions.explanation: Before domestication, brewers relied on ambient wild yeasts to ferment wort.

questions.question: Select all steps that are part of the general brewing process.
correct: Mash malted grain with hot water to make wort
Boil the wort and add bittering/stabilizing agents
Cool the wort to yeast-safe temperatures
incorrect: Soak grain in cold water to extract sugar
Ferment before adding yeast
Add hops after fermentation to sterilize the beer
Expose wort to direct sunlight for clarity
Raise pH with baking soda to speed fermentation
Add bacteria to stabilize the wort
Skip cooling to keep yeast 'excited'
Dry roast the hops before mashing
Filter the wort through coffee grounds for color
Perform a ceremonial dance to appease the yeast
questions.explanation: From the page: mash to create wort; boil with bittering/stabilizing agents; cool; pitch yeast; and ferment. Some texts treat malting as pre-brewing grain preparation.
